poem:
**The Sky Withdraws Its Whisper**

The sky, its invisible thread  
tugged away, a tapestry unraveled—  
decades fold into silence.  
Unseen, the hurricane's breath  
prepares its unknowable waltz,  
while we, unthreaded,  
stand listening to the echo  
of vanished data,  
eyes wide to the furious  
and uncertain horizon,  
awaiting the forgotten  
artistry of air.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Sudden loss of key US satellite data could send hurricane forecasting back ‘decades’ The Department of Defense will halt a critical atmospheric data collection program at the end of June and has given weather forecasters just days to prepare, according to a public notice sent this week. Scientists that the Guardian spoke with say the change could set hurricane forecasting back “decades”, just as this year’s season ramps up. In a National Oceanic and Atmospheric". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
